description: Thought to be from Yiddish קײַקל‎ (kaykl, “circle”). In the early 20th century, Non-English-speaking Jews that immigrated to the United States would sign papers with a circle as opposed to a more common X. The latter symbol was associated by these Jews with the Christian cross, a symbol that represented to them millennia of persecution. This is the dominant etymological theory, but there are others.

entries.meaning: (US, offensive, ethnic slur, religious slur) A Jew.
examples: Synonyms: (not always pejorative) yid, heeb, Hymie, sheeny, shylock

entries.meaning: (US, offensive) A miser; a contemptible, stingy person, particularly a well-endowed one.
examples: That greedy kike would not give me any money when I was starving and needed food.
